column1: WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C. North Carolina will pay up to $5

column6: burning furniture and campaign signs before extinguishing. A swastika and the message ""Nazi Republicans leave town or else"" were spray-painted on a nearby building.""The firebombing of a local political headquarters was clearly an act of intimidation
column7: and I'm going to do everything I can to find the individual or individuals who committed this assault on our democracy

column1: Investigators on Tuesday collected video from locations around the party office

column3: a town of about 6
column4: 400 people located 40 miles (65 km) from the state capital of Raleigh.Evidence from the crime scene is being analyzed at the FBI's laboratory in Quantico
column5: Virginia.

column1: Mike Pence
column2: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's running mate

column1: However
column2: Pence's remarks were well short of allegations by Trump in recent days that the race is being rigged against him at voting locations. column1: By Ayesha Rascoe

WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama welcomed Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi to the White House on Tuesday
column2: using the pomp of the formal state visit to highlight the link between the sluggish European economy and populist discontent in the continent.The spotlight comes at an opportune time for Renzi
column3: who seeks a boost ahead of a constitutional referendum on Dec. 4 that could determine his political future.But even Renzi admitted that the U.S. presidential election on Nov. 8 loomed larger.""I have a feeling
column4: and I think that rightly so
column5: our American friends are a little more interested in November 8 than in the Italian vote on constitutional reform
column6: and so are we
column7: might I add
column8: Renzi said
column9: drawing laughter from the Rose Garden press conference.Obama slammed Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump for ""whining"" that the U.S. election was ""rigged.""

column1: He praised Renzi's proposed economic reforms and said he supported the attempt to modernize political institutions at the referendum because it would help accelerate economic changes.""I do believe that there is a connection between stagnation and some of the less constructive
column2: populist impulses that have been rising up
column3: Obama said
column4: saying more jobs needed to be created for Europe's younger generation.

column1: This is the second time this year Obama has weighed in on domestic political battles facing his European allies. In April
column2: he visited London in support of former Prime Minister David Cameron's unsuccessful efforts to persuade Britain to vote to remain in the European Union. On Tuesday he said he expected Renzi to stay in office for some time.""As you fight for the cause of reform
column3: know that we stand with you. I believe that Italy and the world will continue to benefit from your leadership for many years to come
column4: Obama said during a toast at the state dinner. The leaders discussed the fight against Islamic State and the battle to take the Iraqi city of Mosul from the militant group
column5: something Obama called a ""key milestone.""

column1: Obama insisted the U.S.-led coalition had an extensive strategy to deal with what could be ""heart-breaking"" humanitarian consequences of the fight.The state dinner was the last scheduled for Obama before he leaves office in January. Notable guests included former racing driver Mario Andretti
column2: designer Giorgio Armani
column3: actor Roberto Benigni and celebrity chef Mario Batali
column4: who helped plan and cook the meal. (Additional reporting by Roberta Rampton
column5: Jeff Mason

column1: SHERMANS DALE
column2: Penn. While Donald Trump often rails against a ""rigged"" election on Twitter and at rallies nationwide

column4: a state crucial to the Republican's fading chances to win the White House.Here

column6: his ""rigged"" election message is resonating with his followers in this traditional battleground state where Democratic rival Hillary Clinton has opened up a wide lead. But his calls for poll watchers on Nov. 8 is drawing a mix of confusion
column7: concern and tepid support.In some cases

column9: even though independent studies show U.S. voting chicanery is exceptionally rare and certainly never on a national scale.Since Aug. 8

column22: who are allowed into the polling places and can register official complaints if they think someone isn't a valid voter.

With federal and local candidates both on the November ballot

column6: a realtor from Elliottsburg

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-meteor-idUSKCN12I20S	Trump? Clinton? Many young Americans prefer giant meteor

column1: By Scott Malone

(The 18 October 2016 story was refiled to correct the typo in the last sentence to read likely ""voters"")By Scott MaloneBOSTON Young Americans are so dissatisfied with their choices in this presidential election that nearly one in four told an opinion poll they would rather have a giant meteor destroy the Earth than see Donald Trump or Hillary Clinton in the White House.The tongue-in-cheek question was intended to gauge young Americans' level of unhappiness about their choices in the Nov. 8 election
column2: said Joshua Dyck
column3: co-director of UMass Lowell's Center for Public Opinion
column4: which conducted the poll alongside Odyssey
column5: a social media platform.The choice alluded to the Twitter hashtag ""#GiantMeteor2016
column6: a reference to an imaginary presidential candidate used to express frustration about this year's election choices.Some 53 percent of the 1
column7: 247 people aged 18 to 35 said they would prefer to see a meteor destroy the world than have Republican New York real estate developer Trump in the Oval Office
column8: with some 34 percent preferring planetary annihilation to seeing the Democratic former Secretary of State win.

column1: Some 39 percent said they would prefer that U.S. President Barack Obama declare himself president for life than hand over power to Clinton or Trump
column2: with 26 percent saying the nation would do better to select its next leader in a random lottery.Some 23 percent
column3: nearly one in four
column4: preferred the giant meteor outcome to either Trump or Clinton.""Obviously we don't think that they're serious
column5: Dyck said in a phone interview on Tuesday. ""The fact that one in four of our young people pick 'Giant Meteor' tells you something about the political disaffection that is being shown by American youth.""

column1: That contrasts with the surge of participation by young voters that helped propel Obama into the White House for his first term in the 2008 election.When asked to choose between the actual candidates
column2: Clinton easily led Trump with 54 percent of respondents to 21 percent in a two-way race.

column1: In a four-way race also including Libertarian Gary Johnson and Green Party candidate Jill Stein
column2: Clinton led with 48 percent support
column3: to Trump's 20 percent
column4: Johnson's 10 percent and Stein's 4 percent.In national polls surveying the whole population
column5: Clinton is leading Trump
column6: but not by nearly as much.The poll
column7: conducted Oct. 10-13
column8: intentionally included a large number of people seen as unlikely to vote
column9: with just 680 described as likely voters. It had a margin of error of 3.2 percent. (Reporting by Scott Malone; Additional reporting by Amy Tennery in New York; Editing by Frances Kerry)"	['Clinton'

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN12I27L	Obama tells Trump to 'stop whining' over rigged election claims	"
By Emily Stephenson and Ayesha Rascoe
| WASHINGTON/GRAND JUNCTION
column2: Colo.

column1: WASHINGTON/GRAND JUNCTION
column2: Colo. U.S. President Barack Obama lacerated Donald Trump on Tuesday over his repeated assertions that the Nov. 8 election is rigged against him
column3: telling the Republican presidential candidate to ""stop whining and go try to make his case to get votes.""With opinion polls showing him falling further back against his White House rival
column4: Democrat Hillary Clinton
column5: Trump has intensified his allegations
column6: although numerous studies have shown that voter fraud in U.S. elections is rare.At a campaign rally in Grand Junction
column7: Colorado
column8: Trump continued his attack
column10: ""The press has created a rigged system and poisoned the minds of the voters.""But he also used his speech to detail a new initiative if elected president: a constitutional amendment imposing term limits for members of Congress
column11: six years for members of the House of Representatives
column12: 12 years for members of the Senate.Obama was asked about Trump's voter fraud assertions on Tuesday at a joint news conference in the White House Rose Garden following meetings with Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.He responded with a blistering attack on the Republican candidate
column13: noting that U.S. elections are run and monitored by local officials
column14: who may well be appointed by Republican governors of states
column15: and saying that cases of significant voter fraud were not to be found in American elections.Obama said there was ""no serious"" person who would suggest it was possible to rig American elections
column17: ""I'd invite Mr. Trump to stop whining and go try to make his case to get votes.""Trump
column18: speaking at the Grand Junction rally Tuesday evening
column19: said that Obama should stop campaigning for ""Crooked Hillary"" and ""get out and work on jobs and work on the border.""Trump has raised the possibility for weeks of illegal activities that could tarnish the November election result
column21: including the possibility of votes being cast by dead people
column22: and he has urged his supporters to show up at polling locations on Election Day. He has sharpened his allegations even as Republican lawyers called his assertions unfounded.In a report titled ""The Truth About Voter Fraud
column23: the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University School of Law cited voter fraud incident rates between 0.00004 percent and 0.0009 percent.

column1: An August study by the Washington Post found 31 credible cases of impersonation fraud out of more than 1 billion votes cast in elections from 2000 to 2014. Arizona State University studies in 2012 and 2016 found similarly low rates.In pointed remarks that were part civics lesson
column2: Obama said that if Trump wins on Nov. 8
column3: ""It would be my expectation of Hillary Clinton to offer a gracious concession speech"" and ""it would be my job ... and escort him over to the Capitol
column4: in which there would be a peaceful transfer of power"" at his swearing in.Trump's vice presidential running mate
column5: Mike Pence
column6: took a softer tone than Trump during a campaign appearance in North Carolina
column7: saying he was ""confident"" that the integrity of the election will be ensured.But Pence added that ""in recent years we've had instances
column8: proven instances of voter fraud.""A number of Republican-led states
column9: citing the need to prevent voter fraud
column10: have passed laws with stricter identification requirements. But several have been struck down by courts that ruled they were designed to hinder minority voting.

column1: Trump trails Clinton by 7 points in national opinion polls
column2: according to an average of polls compiled by RealClear Politics.CONTROVERSIES ECLIPSE POLICY DISCUSSION

column1: Over the last few weeks
column2: Trump
column3: who has never previously run for office
column4: has been embroiled in one controversy after another
column5: eclipsing policy issues such as taxes
column6: trade
column7: the economy and national security that normally dominate the final push in presidential campaigns.With three weeks left until Election Day and early voting both by mail and in person already under way in many states
column8: Trump has been grappling with the fallout from the release earlier this month of a 2005 videotape in which he was heard bragging about groping women and making other unwanted sexual advances.

column1: He has said the remarks were just ""locker room"" talk and has strongly denied allegations by a string of women who have come forward since the video emerged to say Trump groped or touched them inappropriately
column2: denouncing his accusers as liars and fame-seekers.The controversies will be the backdrop for the third and final of three presidential debates
column3: to be held on Wednesday evening in Las Vegas.Trump was widely viewed as having been on the defensive during the first debate. He appeared to have improved his performance in the second debate
column4: but according to polling
column5: more voters saw Clinton as the victor.Wednesday's debate
column6: like the first one
column7: will be a traditional format with the moderator posing all the questions. Topics chosen by moderator Chris Wallace include debt and entitlements
column8: immigration
column12: and fitness to be president. At Tuesday's press conference
column13: Obama also criticized Trump for his ""continued flattery"" of Russian President Vladimir Putin
column14: saying ""it is out of step with"" the country.Trump has praised Putin as a strong leader and on Monday suggested that if he wins next month he might meet the Russian leader before he is even sworn in as president. (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe in Washington and Emily Stephenson in Colorado Springs
column15: Colorado; Additional reporting by Susan Heavey and Tim Ahmann in Washington; Writing by Richard Cowan and Alana Wise; Editing by Caren Bohan

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-pollwatchers-idUSKCN12I2WB	U.S. civil rights groups to fan out on Nov. 8 to fight voter intimidation	"
By Andy Sullivan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Donald Trump supporters who plan to stake out polling sites on Election Day may find their own activities tracked closely by thousands of civil-rights activists who are mounting a nationwide effort to prevent problems at the polls.The Republican presidential candidate
column2: who has repeatedly said that the election is rigged
column3: has urged his backers to monitor voting sites for evidence of fraud
column4: raising concerns that overzealous supporters could intimidate voters in the Nov. 8 election.They will not be the only ones out in force on Election Day. Civil rights groups say they plan to deploy thousands of volunteers on the ground in 27 states to ensure that voters will not be turned away by harassment
column5: long lines or confusing rules. Teams of lawyers will file legal challenges if necessary.While previous elections have been marred by irregularities
column6: Trump's rhetoric might lead to greater problems at the polls this year
column7: activists say.""When Trump says
column8: 'Go and watch certain areas of Philadelphia
column9: ' that's either intentionally reckless or it's a thinly veiled call to engage in racial profiling
column11: the head of the American Civil Liberties Union's voting rights project. ""Whether people will heed it
column12: I don't know.""Non-partisan groups have mounted ""election protection"" programs since the disputed Bush-Gore presidential election of 2000
column13: but they faced a more daunting landscape this year even before Trump began warning of a ""rigged election.""

column1: The Supreme Court in 2013 weakened the U.S. government's ability to monitor voting activity in states with a history of racial discrimination
column2: and dozens of Republican-led states have also passed laws that require voters to present photo identification or that restrict voting in other ways.As early voting gets underway in many states
column3: voting-rights groups are publicizing a national hotline
column4: 866-OUR-VOTE
column5: and establishing lines of communication with the election officials who are tasked with resolving problems.""We haven't encountered a situation yet where we feel there's a need to call the police
column6: said Marcia Johnson-Blanco
column7: a co-director of the voting rights project at the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.This year
column8: civil-rights groups are broadening their efforts beyond perpetual battlegrounds like Ohio and Florida to conservative states like Texas
column9: where they plan to field 200 volunteers to monitor polling sites in Houston's Harris County.

column1: We've seen an uptick of folks saying they're going to be out patrolling in a way that we think is trying to be intimidating
column2: said Zenen Jaimes Perez
column3: communications director for the Texas Civil Rights Project. In New York
column4: volunteers with Common Cause are expanding their monitoring programs to Muslim neighborhoods in New York City and some areas of the rural Hudson Valley.""What Trump's efforts have caused us here in New York to think about are places where there are concentrations of voters who
column5: I hate to say
column6: are easy targets - a magnet for people who are extreme
column7: said Susan Lerner
column8: executive director of Common Cause New York.

column1: Democratic officials have stepped up their efforts as well. In Arizona
column2: a traditionally Republican state that is competitive this year
column3: Democrats plans to deploy a record 200 lawyers to make sure that everybody who is in line when polls close at 7 p.m. will get a chance to cast a ballot
column4: said Spencer Scharff
column5: the state party's voter protection director.But at the end of the day
column6: poll monitors do not have the power to fix problems - they can only point them out to election officials.""States have the most important role. They're the ones who write these laws and they have to enforce these laws
column7: said Danielle Davis
column8: a staff attorney at the Advancement Project
column9: a national civil-rights group. (Reporting by Andy Sullivan; Editing by Leslie Adler)"	['Sullivan'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-arizona-executions-idUSKCN12I17E	Arizona execution procedures face review in U.S. court	"
By Jon Herskovitz
A federal judge in Phoenix will hear arguments this week about resuming executions in Arizona
column2: where a 2014 lethal injection that took nearly two hours raised questions about the state's death chamber protocols and the chemicals it uses to kill inmates.The case is the latest to challenge the drugs used in many states to execute prisoners
column3: and may wind up putting the issue back for review by the U.S. Supreme Court.Arizona last year changed its lethal injection procedures following the troubled 2014 execution of Joseph Wood
column4: but lawyers for seven Arizona death row inmates contend new guidelines and drugs will violate U.S. constitutional protections against cruel and unusual punishment.One issue at the hearing set for Wednesday in U.S. district court will be the sedative midazolam
column5: a valium-like drug critics contend does not achieve the level of unconsciousness required for surgery and is therefore unsuitable for executions.The drug was used in Wood's execution along with a narcotic
column6: hydromorphone. He was seen gasping for air during a nearly two-hour procedure where he received 15 rounds of drug injections. Lethal injections are supposed to result in death in a matter of minutes.

column1: Under the new protocols
column2: Arizona has listed one mix where it will use midazolam along with a drug that causes paralysis and another that stops the heart. A similar combination was used in Oklahoma
column3: which had a troubled execution where an inmate was seen twisting on a death chamber gurney.The state said in court papers filed late on Monday it intends to revise its protocols and remove midazolam as an option
column4: pledging not to use it even if it becomes available. It has three other options for lethal injection mixes that do not use the drug in the new protocols. Lawyers for the inmates contend the source of the drugs and their purity have been cloaked in secrecy
column5: since European makers and U.S. pharmaceutical company Pfizer Inc halted sales of drugs used in executions to prison systems in recent years.

column1: As a result
column2: states have turned to lightly regulated compounding pharmacies that mix chemicals. The few states that have obtained lethal injection drugs since then have kept the names of their suppliers confidential.The lawyers want to put future executions on hold while the court reviews the protocols.""Officials in Arizona have fought tooth and nail to protect that secrecy
column3: which
column4: along with the use of an experimental drug combination
column5: only serves to increase the risk of more problematic executions
column6: said Dale Baich
column7: an attorney for the inmates.

column1: The state contends its protocols correct previous problems and it should be permitted to implement capital punishment.""Victims and state governments have rights and interests
column2: too
column3: including an important interest in the timely enforcement of a sentence and the state's interest to enforce its own laws
column4: David Weinzweig argued on behalf of Arizona at a hearing this year. (Reporting by Jon Herskovitz; Editing by Tom Brown)"	[]	[]

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-women-idUSKCN12I2HU	Pro-Trump group ad seeks to pit Michelle Obama against Clinton	"
By Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A Super PAC backing Republican Donald Trump is buying TV airtime in parts of Florida beginning this week for a commercial aimed at using first lady Michelle Obama's words against Hillary Clinton to erode the Democratic presidential candidate's support from women voters in the battleground state.The ad - which the Super PAC has already been running online - shows Michelle Obama in 2007 saying
column2: ""If you can't run your own house
column3: you can't run the White House
column4: which could be taken as a reference to infidelity by Clinton's husband
column5: Bill Clinton.The ad says Michelle Obama was talking about Hillary Clinton. However
column6: at the time
column7: then-candidate Barack Obama denied that his wife's words referred to his opponent for the Democratic presidential nomination.Representatives for Clinton and Michelle Obama declined to comment on the commercial.

column1: The Super PAC
column2: Make America Number 1
column3: is hoping the ad
column4: to be aired in the Orlando and Tampa areas
column5: will resonate with women
column6: a spokesman
column7: Hogan Gidley
column8: told Reuters on Tuesday.

column1: Trump has struggled for support from women voters
column2: many of whom have cited his temperament and past negative comments about women
column3: including comedian Rosie O'Donnell and Fox News host Megyn Kelly.Eleven days ago
column4: the New York businessman's campaign was shaken by the release of a tape showing Trump lewdly bragging about kissing and touching women without their permission. A series of women have since come forward with allegations about such behavior on his part
column5: but he has denied the accusations.In Florida
column6: a Quinnipiac University poll released on Monday found Clinton leading among likely women voters
column7: with support from 54 percent of those surveyed
column8: compared with 39 percent for Trump.

column1: Michelle Obama has become one of the most powerful campaigners for Clinton. A speech the first lady gave in New Hampshire last week attacking Trump for the tape was praised by many as one of the most powerful speeches of the campaign.Make America Number 1 plans to spend $400
column2: 000 to put the ad on TV
column3: spokesman Gidley said.In addition to the TV run
column4: the commercial initially appeared as a Facebook ad. The group spent $72
column5: 000 targeting women in nine key battleground states - states where the vote could swing to either candidate.

column1: Super PACs - or super political action committees - are permitted to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money
column2: but are prohibited by law from coordinating with a campaign. Make America Number 1 is one of a handful of such groups supporting Trump's White House bid.Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton have never directly addressed how they mended their relationship after the fierce 2008 primary campaign
column3: in which Clinton lost to now-President Barack Obama. Both Obamas have campaigned aggressively for Clinton this year.During last week's second presidential debate
column4: Clinton called Michelle Obama ""my friend."" (Reporting by Ginger Gibson; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Clinton'
